entry.title: üöÄ SAP BTP: integraci√≥n inteligente, control financiero y sostenibilidad
entry.content:
Expansi√≥n de SAP BTP hacia los marketplaces de hyperscalers (AWS, Azure, Google Cloud)

SAP ha anunciado que algunos servicios de SAP BTP estar√°n disponibles en los hyperscaler marketplaces en la segunda mitad de 2025. Esto permite que clientes compren y consuman servicios de BTP directamente desde AWS Marketplace, Azure Marketplace, etc., lo que puede simplificar licenciamiento y despliegue. Mejora la flexibilidad en d√≥nde ejecutar servicios, y posiblemente reduzca latencias si se usan infraestructuras cercanas. Tambi√©n implica que los equipos de finanzas deber√°n adaptarse a nuevos modelos de facturaci√≥n. Los clientes podr√°n elegir entre usar BTP desde SAP directamente o v√≠a Marketplace.

Ventajas: m√°s agilidad al aprovisionar servicios, posiblemente mejores acuerdos comerciales locales, menor fricci√≥n operativa, alineaci√≥n con estrategias multicloud/h√≠bridas.

üîó Mas informaci√≥n / https://azuremarketplace.microsoft.com/es-es/marketplace/apps/sapus.btp_us?tab=overview

Nuevas capacidades en SAP HANA Cloud: migraci√≥n selectiva de objetos, gobernanza de costos y monitoreo granular

Se han anunciado mejoras de HANA Cloud que permiten migrar objetos espec√≠ficos de base de datos de un HANA on-premise o cl√°sico hacia HANA Cloud de forma selectiva (no toda la base). Tambi√©n habr√° mayor visibilidad del consumo, gobernanza financiera y monitoreo m√°s granular del uso de recursos. Esto facilita planes de modernizaci√≥n (‚Äòclean core‚Äô) al permitir mover por piezas. Mejora del control de costos operacionales, menor riesgo de sobredimensionamiento. Ideal para empresas que quieren innovar poco a poco.

Ventajas: menos riesgo al migrar; se puede hacer roll-out gradual; permite optimizar qu√© partes de datos o sistemas conviene mover al cloud; optimizaci√≥n del gasto.

üîó Mas informaci√≥n

SAP Customer Identity and Access Management (CIAM) disponible en SAP BTP bajo el Enterprise Agreement

CIAM (Customer Identity & Access Management) ahora est√° incluido como parte de SAP BTP bajo el contrato Enterprise Agreement. Esto aporta una soluci√≥n multitenant, cloud-nativa para manejar identidades de clientes o socios, cumplimiento, privacidad y personalizaci√≥n. Reduce la necesidad de soluciones externas de identidad. Mejora la seguridad de datos de clientes y la experiencia de usuario. Puede alinearse con regulaciones europeas, latinoamericanas, etc., para gesti√≥n de consentimiento y protecci√≥n de datos.

Ventajas: menos componentes externos, integraci√≥n m√°s directa con otras herramientas de SAP, potencial reducci√≥n de coste de licenciamiento externo, mayor coherencia en pol√≠ticas de identidad, visibilidad y auditor√≠a centralizadas.

üîó Mas informaci√≥n

Extensibility Wizard‚Äù para SAP Build y extensiones guiadas desde SAP Business Suite / SAP S/4HANA

SAP ha introducido un Extensibility Wizard (asistente de extensibilidad) que gu√≠a el desarrollo de extensiones tanto para SAP Business Suite como para SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Esto ayuda a estandarizar la forma de extender aplicaciones, asegurando que las extensiones sean compatibles con futuras actualizaciones. Facilita que equipos menos experimentados con ABAP o con extension-points sigan buenas pr√°cticas. Reduce el riesgo de ‚Äúcustom code spaghetti‚Äù. Puede acelerar entregas menores/incrementales sin comprometer el core.

Ventajas: menor tiempo de desarrollo, menos errores, mayor mantenibilidad, mejor preparaci√≥n para upgrades, posibilidad de que las extensiones sean menos costosas de mantener.

üîó Mas informaci√≥n

Integraciones nuevas-predefinidas / adapters adicionales en SAP Integration Suite

SAP Integration Suite est√° incorporando nuevos adapters (conectores) para tecnolog√≠as como IBM MQ, Google Cloud Storage, Salesforce PubSub, Anaplan, Snowflake, etc. Esto ampl√≠a la capacidad out-of-the-box de conectar SAP con sistemas modernos de datos, aplicaciones SaaS, servicios de mensajer√≠a. Se suma la mejora de experiencia de usuario para descubrir contenido preconstruido, recomendaciones, etc. Facilita integraciones h√≠bridas o entre SAP y no-SAP con menor customizaci√≥n.

Ventajas: ahorro de tiempo, mayor estandarizaci√≥n, menor probabilidad de errores en adaptadores hechos a medida, mantenimiento m√°s sencillo. Tambi√©n reduce la barrera para integrar nuevos partners o servicios externos.

üîó Mas informaci√≥n

Mejoras de visibilidad y gobernanza financiera / monitoreo de consumo en los servicios de BTP

SAP est√° reforzando las herramientas de monitoreo del consumo, visibilidad de costos y gobernanza financiera en SAP BTP, especialmente para HANA Cloud, integraci√≥n, servicios que consumen recursos. Esto permite a las empresas anticipar gastos (‚Äúforecast‚Äù) y evitar sorpresas en uso excesivo. Mejores dashboards, alertas, m√©tricas m√°s finas de uso, consumo por objeto o servicio, etc. Tambi√©n se alinea con pol√≠ticas internas de presupuestos, auditor√≠as y optimizaci√≥n de costos.

Ventajas: mayor previsibilidad financiera, identificaci√≥n temprana de cuellos de botella o servicios sub-utilizados, optimizaci√≥n del gasto, facilitar decisiones de cierre vs extensi√≥n del servicio.

üîó Mas informaci√≥n

Estrategia de sostenibilidad con SAP BTP: Control Tower, Footprint Management y Green Ledger

SAP est√° reforzando su portafolio de sostenibilidad, con herramientas como SAP Sustainability Control Tower, Sustainability Footprint Management y SAP Green Ledger, integradas con SAP BTP y SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Estas soluciones permiten capturar datos ESG (ambientales, sociales y de gobierno), automatizar reportes, calcular huella de carbono por producto, y llevar m√©tricas de sostenibilidad al mismo nivel que los reportes financieros. Para organizaciones con regulaci√≥n creciente en est√°ndares ESG, estas capacidades ayudan a cumplir normativas como CSRD y similares, adem√°s de mejorar reputaci√≥n.

Ventajas: visibilidad centralizada de datos ESG, capacidad de reacci√≥n ante exigencias regulatorias, posibilidad de incorporar responsabilidades ambientales en decisiones operativas, v√≠nculo m√°s claro entre sostenibilidad y estrategia de negocio, potencial ahorro a mediano plazo si se optimizan procesos, menos riesgos legales o reputacionales.

üîó Mas informaci√≥n

entry.title: IDOCs are Still Safe for SAP S/4HANA - SAP Clean Core Extensibility Level B
entry.content:
Intro 

IDOCs are safe to use in SAP S/4HANA programs‚Äîand if anyone tells you otherwise, point them to this blog to learn more. IDOCs are now officially part of SAP Clean Core Extensibility! That‚Äôs the big news from updated SAP Guidelines (OSS Note 3578329 ‚Äì Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility).

This ends the myth that IDOCs are ‚Äúdead.‚Äù They are not. They‚Äôre preserved as SAP Clean Core Level B Extensibility, which means your existing IDOC investments are safe. Let‚Äôs explore four perspectives‚Äîintegration, monitoring and error handling, performance, and testing‚Äîto see where APIs are recommended first, and where IDOCs still bring value.

1. Integration Perspective

SAP‚Äôs recommendation for new development in S/4HANA is clear: use modern integration technologies such as APIs, events, or OData services. They are the strategic direction and best fit for greenfield or transformation projects. That said, not all projects require reinvention. If your business processes remain largely the same as in ECC, and the goal is to reduce cost and risk, IDOCs can still be used. They are not prohibited, and as long as an IDOC type is not listed as deprecated in the SAP Simplification List, it is safe:
https://help.sap.com/docs/btc/lean-sdt-best-practices/sap-s-4hana-simplification-analysis?locale=en-US Because IDOCs are now Clean Core Level B Extensibility, continuing with them is fully supported in SAP S/4HANA on-premise and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. They offer a pragmatic path to de-risk projects and leverage existing know-how.‚ÄÉ

2. Monitoring and Error Handling Perspective

For new interfaces, SAP recommends using AIF (Application Interface Framework) to handle monitoring, error management, and business validations. AIF provides a powerful, unified monitoring layer, and in many cases it comes license-free (for standard SAP interfaces delivered in namespaces like /SDSLS or /LEEDI, or in CFIN, Document Compliance, or S/4HANA Public Cloud). Where APIs are deployed, AIF bridges the gap between technical payloads and business-friendly monitoring.

IDOCs still have a strong card here: their monitoring capabilities are mature, well-known, and integrated into standard SAP transactions. Functional users know how to work with WE02, BD87, and standard reprocessing flows. This means less training, less overhead, and faster resolution in day-to-day operations.

In other words: AIF is recommended, but IDOCs deliver proven stability in monitoring and error handling.

3. Performance Perspective

APIs are the recommended way forward, but they come with a structural tradeoff: their payloads are larger and typically handle transactions individually. This makes them more verbose and sometimes less efficient for high-volume use cases. IDOCs, in contrast, have long supported bundling, batching, and parallel processing at scale. They‚Äôve been the backbone of high-volume EDI and SAP-to-SAP integrations for decades, and their ability to handle millions of documents daily is field-proven. So while APIs are the strategic choice for new designs, IDOCs remain a safe performance option for scenarios with heavy data throughput.

4. Testing Perspective

Testing support for APIs exists (for example, with SXI_MONITOR), but it is more technical and often requires additional training for functional teams. For IDOCs, simulation and reprocessing are familiar to almost every SAP functional consultant. Tools like WE19 and BD87 make IDOC testing and troubleshooting accessible, reducing dependency on specialist skills.

For projects that need to standardize and automate testing across both APIs and IDOCs, solutions like Int4 Suite provide simulation and test automation capabilities that unify all SAP integration scenarios. You can learn more on how to test and simulate SAP integrations in this SAP learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization So while APIs are recommended for new developments, IDOCs still offer ease of testing and proven tooling, especially in brownfield projects.

Conclusion

The strategic path forward in SAP S/4HANA is built on APIs, events, and frameworks like AIF. That‚Äôs the official recommendation, and it should guide greenfield and transformation projects. But IDOCs are far from obsolete. They are officially part of Clean Core extensibility, safe to use in both on-premise and private cloud, and carry unique advantages in performance, monitoring, and ease of testing. That makes them not only supported, but still a pragmatic and safe choice when the situation calls for stability, cost reduction, and risk mitigation.

entry.title: Int4 Suite ‚Äî your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
entry.content:
Intro

Want to build reliable Joule skills and agents without breaking anything (or anyone‚Äôs nerves)? Treat Int4 Suite as your Joule testbed and skills builder: a place where you discover the real shape of a skill from historical traffic, scaffold its definition, rehearse end-to-end flows in a safe sandbox, and wire everything into MCP or CI/CD so quality checks can happen automatically.

This post shows a pragmatic playbook for S/4HANA + SAP BTP Integration Suite teams to use Int4 beyond SAP API testing and simulation as a preparation and enablement layer for SAP Business AI.

Why does Int4 belong in your Joule toolchain? 

  • Reality-first inputs. Int4 stores and mines historical electronic messages (IDoc/OData/REST) and master data, gold for grounding AI skills in how your business actually runs.
  • Process-aware, agentic orchestration. It doesn‚Äôt just fire single APIs; it understands and can prepare the business context, chaining SO‚ÜíDelivery‚ÜíInvoice and fixing missing prerequisites on the fly. SAP Community
  • Safe simulation. Int4 Suite virtualizes third-party/partner systems so you can shadow-run agents end-to-end without touching production endpoints.
  • Modern hooks. SAP‚Äôs Joule Studio gives your agents standard tool interfaces; Int4‚Äôs actions and datasets slot right in.

1) Discover the real skill you need (from history)

Problem: Spec sheets rarely match production reality. Which fields are really required? What defaults do users rely on? Which edge cases appear in the wild?

How:

  • Mine historical interface messages across S/4HANA and Integration Suite: pull IDocs, OData/REST payloads for Sales Orders, Deliveries, Invoices, etc. Use them as canonical examples and edge cases for your skill‚Äôs inputs/outputs and constraints.

Figure - Int4 Suite - Robotic Crawler to fetch millions of historical API postings 

  • Reconstruct end-to-end flows (e.g., SO‚ÜíDelivery‚ÜíInvoice) from those messages so your skill spec mirrors the actual business process, not just API docs. This is the core of process-aware agentic testing in Int4. SAP Community

Figure - Int4 Suite - Fix issues with missing stock for a business process posting (outbound delivery part of the Order to Cash process)

Why it matters: You stop guessing which fields matter and start from observed truth, exactly the inputs your Joule skill must handle.

2) Auto-scaffold skill definitions for Joule Studio

Problem: Turning messy real-world payloads into a clean skill I/O schema (and examples) is tedious and easy to get wrong.

How:

  • From mined payloads, extract: required vs. optional fields, typical defaults, allowed value ranges.
  • Turn that into your Joule skill definition (inputs/outputs plus example payloads) in Joule Studio.

Figure - Int4 Suite dimensions created automatically from historical API calls can be used to create Joule skills 

  • Use Int4 Robotic Crawler outputs, hundreds of realistic variants, to seed positive, boundary, and negative examples that harden your prompts/spec.

Why it matters: You get a model-ready spec, grounded in real data, with examples covering the weird cases you‚Äôd otherwise miss.

3) Safe sandboxes for agent rehearsal (‚Äúshadow mode‚Äù)

Problem: Early skills need practice with all their integration touch-points but production endpoints are risky and partners are not always available.

How:

  • Use Int4 Suite to virtualize 3rd-party/partner APIs and even replay historical responses; point your early Joule skill/agent to this sandbox. Run full E2E flows, including error/failure drills, without touching live systems.
  • Pair with SAP S/4 or iFlow stubs so multi-step scenarios can execute safely (e.g., simulate 3PL delivery confirmations, EDI partner messages).

Why it matters: You ‚Äúflight-test‚Äù the skill‚Äôs decisions and error handling in realistic conditions, safely.

4) Wire Int4 Suite into your MCP + CI/CD toolchain

Problem: Skills evolve. APIs and iFlows change. You need automatic quality gates‚Äîevery time.

How:

  • Wrap Int4 actions as MCP tools so your dev copilot or even Joule Studio automations, can call them during build/validation.
  • Let SAP Cloud ALM/DevOps trigger Int4 suites when Joule skills or iFlows change; Int4 already supports automated test-case harvesting and orchestration around Integration Suite.

Why it matters: Every transport becomes self-verifying. Skills can‚Äôt drift out of compliance without getting caught.

How does this complement SAP‚Äôs Business AI?

  • Joule Studio remains where you author skills/agents. Int4 feeds it: schemas, examples, and safe endpoints.
  • MCP servers are how agents call tools; Int4 becomes a tool provider (testing, data seeding, etc.). 
  • Integration Suite + Cloud ALM keep operations clean; Int4 strengthens them with evidence-driven regression around API and iFlow changes.

Figure - Int4 Suite - validate changed APIs or iflows

Where to learn more

  • Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite - why ‚Äúagentic‚Äù tests matter and how Int4 auto-prepares missing context. SAP Community
  • Agentic Testing & Simulation with Int4 Suite‚Äôs SAP Business Knowledge Graph - democratizing simulation & semantic search over test cases. SAP Community
  • Cloud ALM with Integration Suite - monitoring and change-driven automation hooks. SAP Community

entry.title: Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
entry.content:
Intro

Outbound interfaces are the lifeline between your new S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition system and the outside world. Customers, vendors, 3PL partners, they still expect the same EDI (or non-EDI) output messages, even if you‚Äôve reshaped half your internal processes in the course of the SAP S/4HANA transformation.  

The real challenge? Functional consultants need to validate those outbound messages themselves, without waiting on an EDI provider, an integration colleague, or an EDI partner. That‚Äôs where Agentic AI validation with Int4 Suite comes in.

This playbook shows how functional consultants can independently test and validate outbound interfaces, step by step, without leaving the SAP S/4HANA + Int4 Suite environment.

Why functional consultants, not integration teams?

Most SAP projects (Greenfield, Selective Data Transition, or any other complex SAP S/4HANA upgrades) involve huge shifts inside SAP, but the outside world doesn‚Äôt care. Partner EDI flows must remain identical.

Traditionally, testing those flows meant:

  • Asking the EDI partner/provider for some sample messages
  • Trying to run the transaction in SAP S/4HANA
  • Asking the EDI provider to re-check/confirm outbound messages.
  • Pulling in a specialist from the integration team if something takes too long.
  • Repeating the same process multiple times with very little time to do it

Our approach flips this. It empowers the SAP functional consultant to:

  • Insert thousand of historical EDI messages from any productive system
  • Ask Int4 Suite to find the test data within those messages
  • Reproduce SAP transactions from historical payloads, like Sales Order Confirmation, Delivery (ASN) notification, Invoice Notification
  • Validate the EDI outbound messages directly in Int4 Suite by the functional consultant
  • The whole process takes minutes not hours and can be done hundreds of times per hour with no external dependencies (other partners)

No waiting on specialists, no bottlenecks, and much faster iterations.

Step 1: Reality-first message mining with Robotic Crawler

Use the Int4 Robotic Crawler to load hundreds or thousands of real historical messages (EDI or otherwise) into Int4 Suite. These are not toy examples ‚Äî they‚Äôre your actual outbound payloads as they once moved through production.

Figure - Int4 Suite Robotic Crawler can fetch EDI messages from any supported archive or integration platform on mass scale 

Why it matters: Consultants can work with authentic data, not spec sheets or made-up test cases.

Step 2: Conversational selection of test cases

Functional consultants don‚Äôt need to master payload filtering. Instead, they can simply chat with the agent to select which messages they want to test.

Want to see all outbound orders from a specific customer? Or deliveries with a particular Incoterm? Just ask the agent.

Figure - select a historical EDI messages using different criteria (business document, partner, material, etc.) and use this data for testing 

Why it matters: Test-case discovery becomes intuitive, not a technical exercise.

Step 3: Reconstruct SAP business objects from payloads

Once a message is selected, the consultant can instantly recreate a business document (e.g., a Sales Order) inside S/4HANA using the data from that outbound message.

Figure - creating a sales order using the data from the historical EDI message as input 

Now you have a living document in S/4HANA, built directly from the same payload your partners receive.

Why it matters: Consultants can validate the end-to-end logic of their own functional processes, with no dependency on integration experts.

Step 4: Agentic comparison of original vs. new outbound message

After posting the new Sales Order (or Delivery, or Invoice), the consultant sends the newly generated outbound reference back to the AI agent. The agent compares this outbound message to the original one from Step 1.

Figure - use the historical EDI message to compare with the new one and fetch is by just supplying the new order reference number 

Are they still identical? Has anything in S/4HANA configuration changed the outbound structure? Did the partner-facing fields remain untouched?

Figure - display the comparison of the two EDI messages (original and the new one) to fix any SAP S/4HANA configuration issues (like line item category determination, substitutions, calculations, etc.) 

Why it matters: Consultants get a precise answer immediately, without needing to export messages into external systems or call for backup.

Who benefits from this approach?

  • Functional consultants in SAP S/4HANA Greenfield or Selective Data Transition projects who must ensure message stability despite deep process changes.
  • Project teams that want faster, independent validation without pulling scarce EDI resources.
  • Business stakeholders who need assurance that partners will keep receiving the same documents as before, no surprises.

Who is this not for?

  • Integration consultants looking to stress-test iFlows or middleware mappings ‚Äî this isn‚Äôt their playground. Int4 Suite has other features to facilite those requirements.
  • EDI providers who validate full partner connectivity, that‚Äôs still their domain.
  • Pure developers focused on code-level regression, this approach is tailored for business-facing validation.

Why it matters for S/4HANA programs where EDI messages remain the same but SAP S/4HANA can change? 

Outbound interfaces are always the fragile bridge in any migration. By equipping functional consultants with agentic AI validation, you:

  • Shorten test cycles.
  • Reduce reliance on external partners.
  • Increase confidence in project quality.

Outbound messages stay consistent, partners stay happy, and your SAP S/4HANA Greenfield program keeps its velocity.

This approach isn‚Äôt about replacing integration experts ‚Äî it‚Äôs about freeing functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves the system is still what the outside world expects. It‚Äôs the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction interface validation in SAP transformations.

entry.title: New CI Pipeline Restart Extension features: supporting new Pipeline package and improved Restart Job
entry.content:
We are excited to announce the release of Cloud Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store in version 1.0.1.

This update introduces several powerful new features and improvements:

  • Supports new integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration and allows flexible linkage of Generic Pipeline copies to the Pipeline Stages.
  • Enhanced Restart Job Integration Flow:
    • Generic Job Profile to restart all integration scenarios defined in the Partner Directory through the Pipeline Framework.
    • New configuration options to persist the Job Log.
    • New Integration Flow "Pipeline API - Restart Job Log" to retrieve both the Restart Job run list and detailed log data (if log persistence is enabled).
  • Improved configuration and monitoring: New parameters (such as "NotOlderThanHours" for Restart Job), several bug fixes, enriched monitoring headers, and better exception handling.

With these enhancements, version 1.0.1 delivers more flexibility, transparency, and control when managing restarts in your Cloud Integration pipelines.

Integration Package content

New package consists of six Integration Flows, one central Script Collection and one Value Mapping. 2 new artifacts have been added:

  • Pipeline API ‚Äì Restart Job Log (Optional). This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of stored Job Logs. It is built on top of the standard Message Processing Logs (MPL) API and allows either to retrieve the restart job log or to query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs.
  • Value Mapping to determine Pipeline Stage (Optional). The Data Store Entry Name includes a 2-letter code for the Pipeline Stage, derived from the technical name of Pipeline IFlow where the error occurred. This Value Mapping allows to link custom IFlow copies to their Pipeline Stage.

Support for new Pipeline integration packages

The new Cloud Integration Pipeline packages introduce Integration Flows with updated technical IDs that include the version marker ‚Äúv2‚Äù. To ensure compatibility, these new IFlow IDs have been added to the stage determination logic.

In addition, the latest Pipeline version now propagates the MPL ID of the source Pipeline IFlow to the custom error handling IFlow. This allows the Data Store entry name to be built using the original source MPL ID, rather than the MPL ID of the custom error handling flow (as was the case in version 1 of the Cloud Integration Pipeline package).

Pipeline Stage Determination

Each Data Store entry name includes the mandatory attribute Pipeline Stage, which indicates where the exception occurred. In the new version of the Restart Extension, the pipeline stage is resolved through a two-step process. If neither step succeeds, a default value is assigned: Stage (NA) or "Not Assigned".

  1. Technical ID Prefix Check. The system first evaluates the prefix of the source pipeline Integration Flow‚Äôs technical ID. This was the only approach available in version 1.0.0. For example, if you copy a generic Integration Flow to create a receiver-specific outbound pipeline IFlow, the technical ID must start with the correct stage prefix:
    com.sap.integration.cloud.pipeline.v2.generic.step06.outbound.myCustomIFlow is resolved to stage (OB).
  2. Value Mapping Check. If the stage cannot be determined from the prefix, the new version applies a Value Mapping. This mapping links custom IFlow technical IDs to specific pipeline stages, allowing you to flexibly assign non-standard technical IDs to the correct stage (see screenshot).

Generic (Default) Job Profile

In version 1.0.0, the Restart Job IFlow could restart only specific interfaces defined in the Job Profile. One of the most common feedback points was the need for a generic Restart Job, similar to what is available in SAP PO, that could restart all integration scenarios configured for the Cloud Integration Pipeline.

This capability has now been added. With the Generic Restart Job Profile, all scenarios where the Partner ID is determined using the Alternative Partner approach can be restarted in one go. The configuration effort is minimal: the only requirement is that the Job Profile status is set to "active."

Optionally, you can exclude specific integration scenarios from the Generic Restart Job by providing them in the parameter InterfacePidExclusionList.

New Job Profile Parameters

The Restart Job Profile now supports additional optional parameters that extend flexibility and monitoring:

  • NotOlderThanHours. In version 1.0.0, filtering was only possible with the static interval parameters TimeFrom and TimeTo. In the new version, if TimeFrom is not explicitly set, this parameter can dynamically calculate it as: 
TimeFrom = (Job run start timestamp) ‚Äì (Configured number of hours in NotOlderThanHours)
  • RestartJobLog. By default, the job log is stored only in memory within the message header jobLogHeader (accessible only when Trace is activated). With this parameter, you can define where and how the job log is stored:
    • attach ‚Äì the job log is attached to the MPL of the Restart Job IFlow, using the Restart Job ID as MPL Attachment name.
    • persist ‚Äì the job log is persisted in the database using the Persist Message step.
    • custom ‚Äì the job log is sent via a ProcessDirect extension to a custom-built IFlow. In this case, an additional parameter must be maintained in the Job Profile restartJobLogExitEndpoint with the value of ProcessDirect endpoint.

Pipeline API Operations

A new API Integration Flow Pipeline API ‚Äì Restart Job Log has been introduced in the latest package version. This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of Restart Job Logs, provided that the RestartJobLog parameter of the Job Profile is set to either "attach" or "persist".

The following queries are supported:

  • Retrieve the restart job log for a specific Restart Job instance by supplying either the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.
  • Query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs based on selection criteria, in order to obtain the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.

For further details, see the updated Configuration Guide included in the package.

entry.title: A Smarter Move from Boomi and MuleSoft to SAP Integration Suite - Assessed, Automated, Validated
entry.content:
We are living in an era of intelligent transformation, a time when the convergence of digital, physical, and biological worlds is reshaping every facet of our existence. Businesses are evolving with almost breathless speed, with enterprises expanding and adopting new applications, systems, and business models. However, this rapid evolution brings forth a surge in complexity, compelling enterprises to modernise their integration landscape in order to simplify connectivity, improve agility, and reduce operational overhead.

Imagine if your systems spoke the same language, data didn‚Äôt wait in queues, processes moved with instinct, and not instruction, that‚Äôs where SAP Integration Suite takes the lead, not just as a replacement for legacy platforms but as a strategic enabler of digital transformation and landscape consolidation. It silently conducts the symphony weaving APIs, events, processes, and data into a seamless rhythm. Just flowing‚Ä¶.

Why Enterprises Are Making the Shift with SAP Integration Suite

Many organisations who started their journey with legacy middleware are now facing:

  • Fragmented integration landscapes across multiple middleware technologies
  • Rising costs associated with platform sprawl
  • Limited visibility and control over end-to-end processes
  • Challenges in scaling integrations across hybrid and multi-cloud environments

SAP Integration Suite provides a compelling alternative offering native integration with SAP and non-SAP systems, support for hybrid and cloud-native scenarios, and a suite of capabilities for API management, event-driven integration, and process orchestration all in one platform. Cohesion becomes essential when the architecture spans multiple middleware solutions. Consolidating your middleware landscape under one middleware platform brings tangible benefits to an enterprise as it reduces total cost of ownership(TCO) through fewer platforms to manage, maintain and operate. In SAP centric environment, moving to SAP Integration Suite has its advantages. However, the path to consolidation isn‚Äôt always straightforward, especially if the customer‚Äôs landscape has mature middleware platforms like Boomi and MuleSoft.

 Advantages of SAP Integration Suite over Boomi and MuleSoft

  • Smooth Migration from SAP PO/PI
    • SAP Integration Suite: Provides migration automation tool with message mapping automation from SAP PI/PO to SAP IS ensuring smoother transition.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: No direct migration path, customers must redesign integrations from scratch
  • Pre-Package Integration content
    • SAP Integration Suite: Access to SAP API Business Hub with hundreds of pre-built integration flows (iFlows), APIs, and event packages specifically for SAP business processes.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: Offer generic templates and accelerators but limited in-depth SAP
  • Native SAP Connectivity
    • SAP Integration Suite: Comes with pre-built adapters and deep integration with SAP applications (S/4HANA, ECC, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, IBP, etc.), ensuring faster implementation and reduced customization.
    • MuleSoft & Boomi: Require third-party connectors or additional customization to integrate seamlessly with SAP landscapes.

Simplifying Migration from MuleSoft and Boomi with an End-to-End Migration Accelerator Tool

To support enterprises who are on a journey to migrate from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite, we have developed a purpose-crafted accelerator that streamlines the entire lifecycle of migration from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite. This tool helps assess, automate, validate, and govern migrations at scale reducing manual effort, improving accuracy, and accelerating time to value.

Here‚Äôs how it works:

Migration Assessment for MuleSoft & Boomi

  • Analyze's source artifacts (zip/process archives)
  • Identifies APIs, Processes/ Flows, connectors, and backend systems
  • Calculates integration complexity
  • Recommends equivalent SAP adapters
  • Produces a detailed PDF migration report to drive stakeholder alignment

Automated i-Flow Generation

  • Reconstructs source logic into SAP Integration Suite i-Flows
  • Uses pre-built templates for common patterns
  • Offers SAP aligned adapter recommendations through template iflows.
  • Reduces development effort by up to 30%

Mapping Logic Migration

      MuleSoft

  • Parses complex MuleSoft DWL scripts
  • Supports in conversion of DWL to Graphical mapping formats
  • Preserves nested structures and transformation logic
  • Enables plug-and-play use in SAP Integration Suite

      Boomi

  • Conversion of JavaScript to Groovy Script mapping using AI.

Validation & Testing Framework

  • Validation of migrated interfaces.
  • Compares payloads across source and target middleware and flags discrepancies.
  • Reduces test effort significantly.
  • Visual representation of the test results.

Quality Monitoring & Governance Dashboards: enhancing the existing Product monitoring capabilities

  • Provides near real-time visibility into migrated integration flows and API's enhancing the product monitoring capability
  • Customized monitoring alerts and reports of the interfaces based on filters set, through email alerts.
  • Tracks SLA compliance, error trends, and integration health at tenant level
  • AI enabled Error Info chatbot which provides potential causes if error and suggestions  to fix.
  • Version Management dashboard across all tenant in the account.
  • Certificate lifecycle management.
  • Alerting mechanism for failed transactions improving the response time of maintenance and support team.

AI Chatbot for auto documentation of Migration project

  • Generates documents (technical specification, cutover plan etc) associated with migration

So are you ready to modernize Your Middleware Landscape with SAP Integration Suite? Whether you are currently on MuleSoft or Boomi, moving to SAP Integration Suite doesn't have to be daunting. With the right approach and the right tools, you can migrate with confidence, reduce risks, and unlock a future-ready integration landscape with end-to-end automation.

Reach out to learn how we can support your middleware transformation from MuleSoft or Boomi to SAP Integration Suite.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here‚Äôs the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: ‚Äúlearn a test framework and run automated scripts,‚Äù we can say: ‚Äúhere are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.‚Äù

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a ‚ÄúBlack Friday‚Äù scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure ‚Äì run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure ‚Äì fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn‚Äôt care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn‚Äôt about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It‚Äôs about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It‚Äôs the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

More information: 

Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
Int4 Suite ‚Äî your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite
Agentic Testing and Simulation with Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph
